text: Now King David was old and advanced in years, and they covered him with clothes, but he could not get warm.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore his servants said to him, “Let a young virgin be found for my lord the king, and let her stand before the king and care for him, and let her lie by your side so that my lord the king may keep warm.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they searched for a beautiful young woman throughout the land of Israel and found Abishag, a Shunammite, and brought her to the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: She was very beautiful and cared for the king and ministered to him, but the king did not know her intimately.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Adonijah the son of Haggith exalted himself, saying, “I will be king,” and he assembled chariots and horsemen and fifty men to run before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: His father had not confronted him at any time by asking, “Why have you done this?” He also was a very attractive man, and he was born next after Absalom.
speaker: Narrator

text: He conferred with Joab the son of Zeruiah and with Abiathar the priest, and they agreed to help him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Zadok the priest and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada and Nathan the prophet and Shimei and Rei and David’s mighty men did not join Adonijah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adonijah slaughtered sheep and oxen and fat cattle by the Stone of Zoheleth, which is by En Rogel, and invited all his brothers, the king’s sons, and all the men of Judah, the king’s servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he did not invite Nathan the prophet, Benaiah, the mighty men, or his brother Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore Nathan spoke to Bathsheba the mother of Solomon, saying, “Have you not heard that Adonijah the son of Haggith reigns and David our lord does not know it?
speaker: Narrator

text: Now please come and let me give you some advice, so that you may save your own life as well as that of your son Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go to King David and say to him, ‘Did not you, my lord, O king, swear to your handmaid, saying: Assuredly Solomon your son shall reign after me, and he shall sit upon my throne? Why then does Adonijah reign?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then while you are still there talking with the king, I will come in and confirm your words.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Bathsheba went to the king’s chamber. Now the king was very old, and Abishag the Shunammite ministered to him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Bathsheba bowed and prostrated herself before the king.
And the king said, “What do you want?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And she said to him, “My lord, you swore by the Lord your God to your handmaid, saying: Assuredly Solomon your son shall reign after me, and he shall sit upon my throne.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Adonijah reigns, and now, my lord, O king, you are unaware.
speaker: Narrator

text: He has slain oxen and fat cattle and sheep in abundance and has invited all the sons of the king and Abiathar the priest and Joab the commander of the army, but he has not invited your servant Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you, my lord, O king, all the eyes of Israel are upon you that you should tell them who shall sit on the throne of my lord the king after him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Otherwise it shall be that when my lord the king sleeps with his fathers, I and my son Solomon shall be considered offenders.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While she was still talking with the king, Nathan the prophet also came in.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king was told, “Nathan the prophet is here,” and when he entered the king’s presence, he bowed himself before the king with his face to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nathan said, “My lord, O king, have you said, ‘Adonijah shall reign after me, and he shall sit upon my throne’?
speaker: Narrator

text: For he has gone down this day and has slain oxen, fat cattle, and sheep in abundance and has invited all the king’s sons, the commanders of the guard, and Abiathar the priest, and they eat and drink with him, saying, ‘God save King Adonijah!’
speaker: Narrator

text: But he has not invited me, your servant, or Zadok the priest or Benaiah the son of Jehoiada or your servant Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is this thing done by my lord the king, and you have not let your servants know who should sit on the throne of my lord the king after him?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King David answered and said, “Call Bathsheba to me.” And she came into the king’s presence and stood before the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king vowed, “As the Lord lives, who has redeemed my soul out of all distress,
speaker: Narrator

text: even as I swore to you by the Lord God of Israel, saying, ‘Assuredly Solomon your son shall reign after me, and he shall sit upon my throne in my stead,’ even so will I certainly do this day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Bathsheba bowed with her face to the ground in reverence to the king and said, “Let my lord King David live forever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: King David said, “Call Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada for me.” So they came before the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the king said to them, “Take with you the servants of your lord, and cause Solomon my son to ride upon my own mule, and bring him down to Gihon.
speaker: Narrator

text: And let Zadok the priest and Nathan the prophet there anoint him king over Israel, and blow the trumpet and say, ‘God save King Solomon!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you shall come up after him. And he shall come and sit on my throne, for he will be king in my place as I have appointed him to be ruler over Israel and over Judah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Benaiah the son of Jehoiada answered the king and said, “Amen! May the Lord, the God of my lord the king, also say so!
speaker: Narrator

text: As the Lord has been with my lord the king, may He also be with Solomon and make his throne greater than the throne of my lord King David.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, and the Kerethites and the Pelethites went down and had Solomon ride on King David’s mule and brought him to Gihon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zadok the priest took a horn of oil out of the tabernacle and anointed Solomon. Then they blew the trumpet, and all the people said, “God save King Solomon!”
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people came up to see him and played flutes and greatly rejoiced, so that the earth shook at the sound.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adonijah and all the guests that were with him heard the commotion as they were finishing their meal, and when Joab heard the sound of the trumpet, he said, “Why is the city so loud and in an uproar?”
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was speaking, Jonathan the son of Abiathar the priest came. Adonijah said to him, “Come in, for you are a valiant man and bring good tidings.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan answered Adonijah, saying, “Surely our lord King David has made Solomon king.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king has sent with him Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, and the Kerethites, and the Pelethites. And they had him ride on the king’s mule.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Zadok the priest and Nathan the prophet have anointed him king in Gihon, and they have come up from their rejoicing, so that the city is in an uproar. This is the noise that you heard.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also Solomon sits on the throne of the kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, the king’s servants came to bless our lord King David, saying, ‘May God make the name of Solomon better than your name and make his throne greater than your throne.’ And the king bowed himself upon the bed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king also said, ‘Blessed be the Lord God of Israel, who has given one to sit on my throne this day so that I could see with my own eyes.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: All the guests that were with Adonijah were afraid and rose up and went on their way.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adonijah feared Solomon. So he got up and went to the altar and held on to its horns.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Solomon was told, “Adonijah fears King Solomon, for he has caught hold of the horns on the altar, saying ‘Let King Solomon swear to me today that he will not slay his servant with the sword.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Solomon said, “If he will show himself a worthy man, not one of his hairs will fall to the ground, but if wickedness is found in him, he shall die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So King Solomon sent for him, and they brought him down from the altar, and he came and bowed himself to King Solomon. And Solomon said to him, “Go to your house.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now it was coming close to the day of David’s death, and he gave his son Solomon a charge, saying:
speaker: Narrator

text: “I am going the way of all the earth. Be strong, and show yourself to be a man.
speaker: Narrator

text: And keep the charge of the Lord your God, walking in His ways, keeping His statutes, His commandments, His judgments, and His testimonies, as it is written in the Law of Moses, that you may prosper in all that you do and wherever you turn,
speaker: Narrator

text: that the Lord may carry out His word that He spoke concerning me, saying, ‘If your children take heed to their way, to walk before Me in faithfulness with all their hearts and with all their souls, you shall not fail to have a man on the throne of Israel.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Moreover, you know also what Joab the son of Zeruiah did to me, what he did to the two commanders of the army of Israel, to Abner the son of Ner and to Amasa the son of Jether, whom he killed, shedding the blood of war in a time of peace. He spilled their blood on the belt that was around his waist and on the shoes of his feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do the right thing according to your wisdom, and do not let his gray head go down to the grave in peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But show kindness to the sons of Barzillai the Gileadite, and let them eat at your table, for with such loyalty they supported me when I fled from your brother Absalom.
speaker: Narrator

text: “There is also with you Shimei the son of Gera, a Benjamite from Bahurim, who cursed me with a grievous curse in the day when I went to Mahanaim. But when he came down to meet me at the Jordan, I swore to him by the Lord, saying, ‘I will not put you to death with the sword.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore do not hold him guiltless, for you are a wise man and know what you ought to do to him. Bring his gray head down to the grave with blood.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David slept with his fathers and was buried in the City of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: David reigned over Israel forty years. He reigned seven years in Hebron and thirty-three years in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Solomon sat upon the throne of his father David, and his kingdom was firmly established.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Adonijah the son of Haggith came to Bathsheba the mother of Solomon. And she said, “Do you come in peace?”
And he said, “I come peaceably.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he said, “I have something to say to you.”
And she said, “Speak.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “You know that the kingdom was mine and that all Israel viewed me as the king. However, the kingdom has become my brother’s, for it was given to him by the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And now I ask one petition of you; do not deny me.”
She said to him, “Keep speaking.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said, “Please speak to Solomon the king, for he will not refuse you, that he may give me Abishag the Shunammite as a wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Bathsheba said, “Very well, I will speak to the king on your behalf.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Bathsheba went to King Solomon to speak to him on behalf of Adonijah. The king rose up to meet her and bowed to her. Then he sat down on his throne and had a seat placed at his right hand for her to sit upon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then she said, “I desire one small petition of you. Please do not deny me.”
And the king said to her, “Ask, my mother, for I will not refuse you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She said, “Let Abishag the Shunammite be given as a wife to Adonijah your brother.”
speaker: Narrator

text: King Solomon answered his mother, “Now why do you ask Abishag the Shunammite for Adonijah? Ask for him the kingdom also, for he is my elder brother. Ask not only for him, but also for Abiathar the priest, and for Joab the son of Zeruiah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King Solomon swore by the Lord, saying, “May God do so to me and more also if this word does not cost Adonijah his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore as the Lord lives, who has established me and set me on the throne of David my father and who has made me a house as He promised, Adonijah shall be put to death this day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So King Solomon dispatched Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, and he executed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said to Abiathar the priest, “Go to Anathoth, to your own fields, for you are worthy of death. But I will not at this time put you to death, because you bore the ark of the Lord God before David my father and because you shared in all the hardships my father endured.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Solomon expelled Abiathar from being priest to the Lord, thus fulfilling the word of the Lord that He had spoken concerning the house of Eli in Shiloh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then word came to Joab, for Joab had followed Adonijah, though he did not support Absalom. And Joab fled to the tabernacle of the Lord and caught hold of the horns of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Solomon was told that Joab had fled to the tabernacle of the Lord and was by the altar. Then Solomon sent Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, saying, “Go and execute him.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Benaiah came to the tabernacle of the Lord and said to him, “Thus says the king, ‘Come forth.’ ”
And he said, “No, I will die here.”
And Benaiah told the king all Joab said.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said to him, “Do as he has said, strike him down and bury him, and thus take away from me and my father’s house the guilt for the blood Joab shed without cause.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord shall return his blood upon his own head, for he attacked two men more righteous and better than he—Abner the son of Ner, commander of the army of Israel, and Amasa the son of Jether, commander of the army of Judah—and killed them with the sword when my father David was unaware.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore their blood shall return upon the head of Joab and upon the head of his seed forever, but upon David and upon his seed and upon his house and upon his throne shall the peace of the Lord rest forever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Benaiah the son of Jehoiada went up and attacked and killed him, and he was buried in his own house in the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king put Benaiah the son of Jehoiada over the army in place of Joab and put Zadok the priest in the place of Abiathar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king sent and called for Shimei and said to him, “Build a house for yourself in Jerusalem, and dwell there, and never leave the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: For on the day you go out and pass over the Kidron Valley, know for certain that you will surely die. Your blood shall be on your own head.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Shimei said to the king, “What you say is good. As my lord the king has said, so will your servant do.” And Shimei lived in Jerusalem many days.
speaker: Narrator

text: It came about that at the end of three years, two servants of Shimei ran away to Achish son of Maakah king of Gath. And they told Shimei, saying, “Your servants are in Gath.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Shimei arose, saddled his donkey, and went to Gath to Achish to look for his servants. And Shimei went and brought his servants from Gath.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon was told that Shimei had gone from Jerusalem to Gath and had returned.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king sent and called for Shimei and said to him, “Did I not make you swear by the Lord and warned you, saying, ‘Know for certain that on the day you go out and walk abroad anywhere, you shall surely die’? And you said to me, ‘What you say is good; I will obey.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Why then have you not kept the oath of the Lord and the commandment that I gave you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king also said to Shimei, “You know all the wickedness in your heart and what you did to David my father. Therefore the Lord shall return your wickedness on your own head.
speaker: Narrator

text: But King Solomon shall be blessed, and the throne of David shall be established before the Lord forever.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the king commanded Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, who went out and attacked him so that he died.
And the kingdom was established in the hand of Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon made a treaty with Pharaoh king of Egypt. He married Pharaoh’s daughter and brought her to the City of David until he finished building his palace, the house of the Lord, and the wall around Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people were sacrificing at the high places, because no house had yet been built for the name of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon loved the Lord, walking in the statutes of his father David, though he sacrificed and burned incense at the high places.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king went to Gibeon to sacrifice there, for that was the great high place, and he offered a thousand burnt offerings on that altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was in Gibeon, the Lord appeared to Solomon in a dream at night, and He said, “Ask what you want from Me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon answered, “You have shown great mercy to your servant David my father, because he walked before You in faithfulness, righteousness, and uprightness of heart toward You. And You have shown him great kindness in giving him a son to sit on his throne this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now, O Lord, my God, You have made Your servant king in place of my father David, and I am still a little child and do not know how to go out or come in.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Your servant is in the midst of Your people whom You have chosen, a great people, so numerous that they cannot be numbered or counted.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give Your servant therefore an understanding heart to judge Your people, that I may discern between good and bad, for who is able to judge among so great a people?”
speaker: Narrator

text: It pleased the Lord that Solomon had asked this.
speaker: Narrator

text: God said to him, “Because you have asked this and have not asked for yourself long life or riches or the lives of your enemies, but have asked for yourself wisdom so that you may have discernment in judging,
speaker: Narrator

text: I now do according to your words. I have given you a wise and an understanding heart, so that there has never been anyone like you in the past, and there shall never arise another like you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have also given you what you have not asked, both riches and honor, so that no kings will compare to you all of your days.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you will walk in My ways, keeping My statutes and My commandments as your father David did, then I will lengthen your days.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Solomon awoke and found it was a dream.
Then he came to Jerusalem and stood before the ark of the covenant of the Lord and offered up burnt offerings and peace offerings and made a feast for all of his servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time, two women who were prostitutes came and stood before the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first woman said, “O my lord, this woman and I live in the same house, and I bore a child with her in the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Three days after I gave birth, she also had a child, and we were together. There was no one else with us in the house, only the two of us were in the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then this woman’s child died during the night because she rolled over on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: She got up at midnight and took my son from beside me while your servant slept and laid him at her bosom and laid her dead child at my bosom.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I rose in the morning to feed my child, it was dead. But when I looked closely in the morning light, I recognized that it was not my son whom I bore.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The other woman said, “No, the living is my son, and the dead is your son.”
And she said, “No, the dead is your son, and the living is my son.” Thus they spoke before the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king said, “One says, ‘This is my son who lives, and your son is the dead,’ and the other says, ‘No, but your son is dead, and my son is the living.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king said, “Bring me a sword.” And they brought a sword before the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said, “Divide the living child in two, and give half to the one and half to the other.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the woman whose child was the living one spoke to the king, for she yearned with compassion for her son, and she said, “O my lord, give her the living child, and do not kill it.”
But the other said, “Let it be neither mine nor yours and divide it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king answered and said, “Give her the living child, and do not slay it. She is its mother.”
speaker: Narrator

text: All Israel heard of the king’s judgment, and they feared the king, for they saw that the wisdom of God was in him, to execute sound judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: So King Solomon was king over all Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These were the officials in his court:
Azariah the son of Zadok was the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Elihoreph and Ahijah, the sons of Shisha, were secretaries.
Jehoshaphat the son of Ahilud was the recorder;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Benaiah the son of Jehoiada was over the army.
Zadok and Abiathar were priests.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Azariah the son of Nathan was over the officers,
and Zabud the son of Nathan was principal officer and the king’s friend.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ahishar was over the household,
and Adoniram the son of Abda was over the forced labor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon had twelve officers over all Israel who made provision for the king and his household. Each man was assigned a month to make provision.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These are their names:
the son of Hur in Mount Ephraim;
speaker: Narrator

text: the son of Deker in Makaz and in Shaalbim and Beth Shemesh and Elon Bethhanan;
speaker: Narrator

text: the son of Hesed in Arubboth (to him belonged Sokoh and all the land of Hepher);
speaker: Narrator

text: the son of Abinadab in all the region of Dor (he had Taphath the daughter of Solomon as his wife);
speaker: Narrator

text: Baana the son of Ahilud in Taanach, Megiddo, and all Beth Shan that is by Zarethan beneath Jezreel, and from Beth Shan to Abel Meholah as far as the other side of Jokmeam;
speaker: Narrator

text: the son of Geber in Ramoth Gilead (to him pertained the towns of Jair the son of Manasseh which are in Gilead, and also the region of Argob which is in Bashan, sixty great cities with walls and iron bars);
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahinadab the son of Iddo in Mahanaim;
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahimaaz in Naphtali (he had taken Basemath the daughter of Solomon as his wife);
speaker: Narrator

text: Baana the son of Hushai in Asher and in Aloth;
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat the son of Paruah in Issachar;
speaker: Narrator

text: Shimei the son of Ela in Benjamin;
speaker: Narrator

text: Geber the son of Uri in the country of Gilead, the country of Sihon king of the Amorites and of Og king of Bashan. He was the only officer who was in that region.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah and Israel had a large populace, as numerous as the sand by the sea. They ate and drank and were happy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon reigned over all kingdoms from the River to the land of the Philistines and to the border of Egypt. The people brought presents and served Solomon all the days of his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon’s provision for one day was thirty kors of fine flour and sixty kors of meal,
speaker: Narrator

text: ten fat oxen and twenty pasture-fed cattle, a hundred sheep in addition to deer, roebucks, gazelle, and fatted poultry.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he had dominion over all the region on this side of the River from Tiphsah to Gaza, over all the kings on this side of the River, and he had peace on all borders of his land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah and Israel lived safely, every man under his vine and under his fig tree, from Dan to Beersheba all the days of Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon had forty thousand stalls of horses for his chariots and twelve thousand horsemen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those officers made provision for King Solomon and for all who came to King Solomon’s table, every man in his month, and they lacked nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Barley also and straw for the horses and dromedaries were brought to the place where the officers were, every man according to his charge.
speaker: Narrator

text: God gave Solomon wisdom and great depth of understanding as well as compassion, as vast as the sand on the seashore.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon’s wisdom excelled the wisdom of all the people of the East country and all the wisdom of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he was wiser than all other men, wiser than Ethan the Ezrahite, Heman, Kalkol, and Darda, the sons of Mahol; his fame spread throughout all the surrounding nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: He spoke three thousand proverbs, and his songs numbered a thousand and five.
speaker: Narrator

text: He spoke of trees, from the cedar tree that is in Lebanon to the hyssop that springs out of the wall. He also spoke of beasts and of fowl and of insects and fish.
speaker: Narrator

text: People from all over came to hear the wisdom of Solomon, from all kings of the earth, who had heard of his wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Hiram king of Tyre sent his servants to Solomon, for he had heard that they had anointed him king in place of his father, and Hiram had always loved David.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Solomon sent word to Hiram, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “You know how David my father was unable to build a house for the name of the Lord his God because of the wars all around him, until the Lord put his enemies under his feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now the Lord my God has given me peace on every side, so that there is neither adversary nor misfortune.
speaker: Narrator

text: So know that I plan to build a house to honor the name of the Lord my God, just as the Lord spoke to my father David, saying, ‘Your son, whom I will set on your throne after you, shall build a house to honor My name.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now therefore command that cedar trees from Lebanon be cut down for me, and my servants shall be with your servants, and I will pay your servants whatever you command, for you know that there are none among my people who can cut timber like the Sidonians.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Hiram heard the words of Solomon, he rejoiced greatly and said, “Blessed be the Lord this day, who has given David a wise son over this great people.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hiram sent to Solomon, saying,
“I have considered the things which you contacted me about, and I will do all you asked concerning timber of cedar and fir.
speaker: Narrator

text: My servants shall bring them down from Lebanon to the sea, and I will send them by sea in floats to the place that you shall name and will cause them to be discharged into your care there, and in return you will meet my wishes by giving food for my household.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Hiram gave Solomon cedar trees and fir trees as he desired.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon gave Hiram twenty thousand kors of wheat for his household and twenty baths of pure oil. This is what Solomon gave to Hiram each year.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord gave Solomon wisdom, as He promised, and there was peace between Hiram and Solomon as they made a treaty together.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Solomon drafted men from all Israel, totaling thirty thousand men.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent them to Lebanon in turns, ten thousand a month, with each spending a month in Lebanon and two months at home. Adoniram administered the labor force.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon had seventy thousand porters and eighty thousand stonecutters in the mountains,
speaker: Narrator

text: not counting the chief of Solomon’s officers who were over the work, three thousand three hundred, who ruled over the people who did the work.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the king’s command, they quarried out great, costly stones in order to lay the foundation of the house with dressed stones.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon’s builders and Hiram’s builders, along with the stonemasons, cut them and prepared timber and stones to build the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the four hundred and eightieth year after the children of Israel came out of the land of Egypt, in the fourth year of Solomon’s reign over Israel, in the month Ziv (which is the second month), he began to build the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The house which King Solomon built for the Lord had a length of sixty cubits, a width of twenty cubits, and a height of thirty cubits.
speaker: Narrator

text: The porch in front of the temple was twenty cubits in length, the same as the width of the house, and ten cubits deep in front of the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made beveled windows for the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also built a structure against the wall of the house, running around the walls of the house, both of the temple and of the inner sanctuary, and he made side chambers all around.
speaker: Narrator

text: The lowest story was five cubits broad, the middle one was six cubits broad, and the third was seven cubits broad. For around the outside of the house, he made offsets on the wall so that the supporting beams should not be inserted into the walls of the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: The house was built of stone prepared at the quarry, so that neither hammer nor axe nor any tool of iron was heard in the house while it was being built.
speaker: Narrator

text: The door for the middle chamber was in the right side of the house, and it had winding stairs into the middle chamber and out of the middle into the third.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he built the house and finished it and covered it with beams and boards of cedar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he built chambers against the whole house, five cubits high, and they rested on the house with timber of cedar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the word of the Lord came to Solomon, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Concerning this house which you are building, if you will walk in My statutes and execute My judgments and keep all My commandments and walk in them, then I will carry out My word with you, which I spoke to David your father,
speaker: Narrator

text: and I will dwell among the people of Israel and will not forsake My people Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Solomon built the house and finished it.
speaker: Narrator

text: He built the interior walls of the house with boards of cedar. From the floor of the house to the ceiling, he covered them on the inside with wood; and he covered the floor of the house with planks of fir.
speaker: Narrator

text: He lined twenty cubits on the sides of the house, both the floor and the walls, with boards of cedar, and he even lined them within, even the inner sanctuary and the Most Holy Place.
speaker: Narrator

text: The house, that is, the nave in front of the inner sanctuary, was forty cubits long.
speaker: Narrator

text: The cedar of the house within had carvings of gourds and open flowers. All was cedar. There was no stone seen.
speaker: Narrator

text: He prepared the inner sanctuary in the inner part of the house in order to set there the ark of the covenant of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The inner sanctuary was twenty cubits long, twenty cubits wide, and twenty cubits high. He overlaid it with pure gold. He also overlaid the altar of cedar.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Solomon overlaid the interior of the house with pure gold, and he made a partition with gold chains in front of the inner sanctuary, and he overlaid it with gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: He overlaid the whole house with gold as well as the whole altar that was by the inner sanctuary.
speaker: Narrator

text: Within the inner sanctuary, he made two cherubim from olive wood, each ten cubits high.
speaker: Narrator

text: One wing of the cherub was five cubits, and the other wing was also five cubits. From the furthest part of the one wing to the furthest part of the other was ten cubits.
speaker: Narrator

text: The other cherub was ten cubits. Both the cherubim were the same shape and size.
speaker: Narrator

text: The height of the one cherub was ten cubits, and so was that of the other cherub.
speaker: Narrator

text: He set the cherubim within the inner sanctuary, and they stretched forth the wings of the cherubim, so that the wing of the one touched the one wall and the wing of the other cherub touched the other wall, and their wings touched one another in the middle of the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: He overlaid the cherubim with gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: He carved all the walls of the house with carved figures of cherubim and palm trees and open flowers both inside and out.
speaker: Narrator

text: He overlaid the floor of the house with gold, both inside and out.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the entrance to the inner sanctuary, he made doors of olive wood; the lintel and doorposts were five-sided.
speaker: Narrator

text: The two doors were also made of olive wood. He carved on them cherubim, palm trees, and open flowers, overlaid them with gold, and spread gold upon the cherubim and upon the palm trees.
speaker: Narrator

text: So also he made for the entrance to the nave four-sided posts of olive wood.
speaker: Narrator

text: The two doors were made from fir tree, with two leaves of each door folding.
speaker: Narrator

text: He carved on them cherubim and palm trees and open flowers and covered them with gold fitted upon the carved work.
speaker: Narrator

text: He built the inner court with three rows of hewed stone and a row of cedar beams.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fourth year, in the month Ziv, the foundation of the house of the Lord was laid,
speaker: Narrator

text: and in the eleventh year, in the month Bul (which is the eighth month), the house was completely finished. All the details and plans were met. So he took seven years to build it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon was building his own house for thirteen years, and he finished all his house.
speaker: Narrator

text: He built the House of the Forest of Lebanon. Its length was a hundred cubits, and its width was fifty cubits, and its height was thirty cubits, built on four rows of cedar pillars with cedar beams upon the pillars.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was covered with cedar over the top of the beams, which sat upon forty-five pillars, fifteen in a row.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were window frames in three rows and window opposite window in three tiers.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the doors and posts were rectangular with the openings facing each other in three tiers.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made a porch of pillars with a length of fifty cubits and a breadth of thirty cubits. There was a porch in front with pillars, and a canopy in front of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he made a porch for the throne, from which he would judge, and called it the Hall of Judgment. It was covered with cedar from one side of the floor to the other.
speaker: Narrator

text: His own house where he lived, in the other court back of the hall, was similar in style. Solomon also made a house like this for Pharaoh’s daughter, whom he had taken as a wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: All these were built with costly stones, cut to size and sawed with saws on the inside and outside, from the foundation up to the coping, throughout the outside toward the great court.
speaker: Narrator

text: The foundation was of large, costly stones, stones of ten and eight cubits in size.
speaker: Narrator

text: Above were costly stones cut to size, along with cedars.
speaker: Narrator

text: The great court was enclosed with three rows of hewed stones and a row of cedar beams. So were the inner court of the house of the Lord and the porch of the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now King Solomon sent and called Huram out of Tyre.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was the son of a widow from the tribe of Naphtali, and his father was a man of Tyre who worked in bronze, and he was filled with wisdom and understanding and skill to make all sorts of items in bronze. So he came to King Solomon and performed all his work.
speaker: Narrator

text: He cast two pillars of bronze eighteen cubits high each and twelve cubits in circumference.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made two capitals of cast bronze to set on the tops of the pillars. The height of the one capital was five cubits, and the height of the other capital was five cubits.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made lattices of checker work with wreaths of chainwork for the capitals on top of the pillars: seven for one capital and seven for the other.
speaker: Narrator

text: Likewise he made pomegranates in two rows around the one latticework to cover the capital that was on the top of the pillar, and he did the same for the other capital.
speaker: Narrator

text: The capitals that were on top of the pillars in the porch were four cubits high and in the shape of lilies.
speaker: Narrator

text: The capitals on top of the two pillars also had pomegranates above, by the convex surface which was next to the latticework. There were two hundred pomegranates in rows encircling each capital.
speaker: Narrator

text: He set up the pillars in the porch of the temple. He set up the right pillar and called it Jakin, and he set up the left pillar and called it Boaz.
speaker: Narrator

text: The tops of the pillars were in the shape of lilies. This completed the work on the pillars.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made a cast metal sea, ten cubits from one side to the other. It was round and had a height of five cubits, and a line of thirty cubits encircled it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Under the brim all the way around there were gourds, ten in a cubit. When it was cast, the gourds were placed in two rows going all the way around it.
speaker: Narrator

text: It stood on top of twelve oxen with three facing north, three facing toward the west, three facing toward the south, and three facing toward the east. The sea was set on them, and their hindquarters were turned inward.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was a hand-breadth thick, and the brim was made similar to the brim of a cup, like a lily blossom. It could hold two thousand baths.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made ten stands out of bronze, each measuring four cubits long, four cubits wide, and three cubits high.
speaker: Narrator

text: The work of the stands looked like this: They had panels, and the panels were set in the frames.
speaker: Narrator

text: And on the panels that were set in the frames were lions, oxen, and cherubim. On the frames both above and below the lions and oxen, there were wreaths of beveled work.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every stand had four bronze wheels and axles of bronze, and at the four corners were supports for a basin. The supports were cast with wreaths at the side of each.
speaker: Narrator

text: Its opening was within a crown that projected upward one cubit. Its opening was round, like the work of a pedestal, a cubit and a half deep. At its opening there were engravings, and its panels were four-sided, not round.
speaker: Narrator

text: Underneath the panels were four wheels, and the axles of the wheels were joined to the stand, and the height of a wheel was a cubit and a half.
speaker: Narrator

text: The wheels worked like chariot wheels in that their axles and rims and spokes and hubs were all cast metal.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were four supports for the four corners of each stand, and the supports were part of one piece with the stand itself.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the top of the stand, there was a round band half a cubit high, and on the top of the stand its stays and its panels were of one piece with it.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the surface of its stays and on its panels, he engraved cherubim, lions, and palm trees, according to the space of each, with wreaths all around.
speaker: Narrator

text: In this way he made the ten stands, with them all having the same shape, measure, and size.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he made ten basins of bronze, with each basin able to hold forty baths, each being four cubits. Upon every one of the ten stands sat one basin.
speaker: Narrator

text: He put five stands on the right side of the house, and five on the left side of the house. He set the sea on the right side of the house toward the southeast.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Huram also made the pots, the shovels, and the basins.
So Huram finished all the work in making items for King Solomon for use in the house of the Lord:
speaker: Narrator

text: the two pillars, the two bowls of the capitals that were on the top of the two pillars, the two latticeworks to cover the two bowls of the capitals that were upon the top of the pillars;
speaker: Narrator

text: and the four hundred pomegranates for the two latticeworks, two rows of pomegranates for each latticework, to cover the two bowls of the capitals that were on the pillars;
speaker: Narrator

text: the ten stands and ten basins on the stands;
speaker: Narrator

text: one sea and twelve oxen under the sea;
speaker: Narrator

text:
the pots, the shovels, and the basins.
All these vessels that Huram made for King Solomon for the house of the Lord were of burnished bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the plain of the Jordan the king cast them, in the clay ground between Sukkoth and Zarethan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon left all the vessels unweighed because there were so many. The weight of the bronze was also never measured.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon made all the vessels that were needed for the house of the Lord: the altar of gold, the table of gold on which was showbread,
speaker: Narrator

text: the candlesticks of pure gold, five on the right side and five on the left before the inner sanctuary; the flowers, the lamps, and the tongs, of gold;
speaker: Narrator

text: the cups, snuffers, basins, dishes for incense, fire pans, of pure gold; the sockets for the doors of the innermost part of the house, the Most Holy Place, and for the doors of the nave of the temple, of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the work that King Solomon made for the house of the Lord was completed. And Solomon brought in the things which David his father had dedicated—the silver, the gold, and the cups—and he put them among the treasures of the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Solomon assembled the elders of Israel and all the heads of the tribes, the chief of the fathers of the children of Israel, before King Solomon in Jerusalem, so that they could ensure that the ark of the covenant of the Lord would be brought out of the City of David in Zion.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the men of Israel assembled themselves before King Solomon at the feast in the month Ethanim, which is the seventh month.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the elders of Israel came, and the priests carried the ark.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priests and Levites brought up the ark of the Lord, the tabernacle of the congregation, and all the holy implements that were in the tabernacle.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Solomon and all the congregation of Israel who were assembled before him stood together in front of the ark, sacrificing so many sheep and oxen that they could not be told or numbered.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priests brought in the ark of the covenant of the Lord to its place in the inner sanctuary of the house, to the Most Holy Place under the wings of the cherubim.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the cherubim spread forth their two wings over the place of the ark and covered the ark and the poles from above.
speaker: Narrator

text: The poles were so long that the ends of the poles could be seen out in the holy place in front of the inner sanctuary, but they could not be seen from outside, and they are there to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was nothing in the ark except for the two tablets of stone that Moses put there at Horeb when the Lord made a covenant with the children of Israel after they had come out of the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the priests came out of the holy place, the cloud filled the house of the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that the priests could not continue to minister because of the cloud, for the glory of the Lord filled the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Solomon spoke, saying, “The Lord said that He would dwell in the thick darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have surely built You a house to dwell in, a settled place for You to abide in forever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king turned around and blessed all the congregation of Israel (and all the congregation of Israel stood),
speaker: Narrator

text:
and he said,
“Blessed be the Lord God of Israel, who spoke with His mouth to my father David and has with His hand fulfilled His word, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Since the day that I brought forth My people Israel out of Egypt, I chose no city from any tribe of Israel to build a house where My name might be praised, but I chose David to be over My people Israel.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “My father David had it in mind to build a house for the name of the Lord God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to my father David, ‘Whereas it was in your heart to build a house for My name, you had good intentions.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, you shall not build the house, but your son who will come out of your loins, he shall build the house for My name.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord has fulfilled His word that He spoke, and I have been elevated to the position of my father David, to sit on the throne of Israel as the Lord promised, and have built a house for the name of the Lord God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have set a place there for the ark, which houses the covenant of the Lord which He made with our fathers when He brought them out of the land of Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Solomon stood in front of the altar of the Lord in the presence of all the congregation of Israel and spread his hands toward heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text:
and he said,
“Lord God of Israel, there is no God like You in heaven above or on earth below who keeps covenant and mercy with Your servants who walk before You with all their hearts,
speaker: Narrator

text: who have kept what You promised Your servant David my father. You spoke also with Your mouth and have fulfilled it with Your hand, as it is this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Therefore, Lord God of Israel, now keep what You promised Your servant David my father, saying, ‘You will not fail to have a man sit before Me on the throne of Israel, so long as your sons take heed to their way, that they walk before Me as you have walked before Me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, O God of Israel, let Your word, I pray, be fulfilled, which You spoke to Your servant David my father.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But will God indeed dwell on the earth? See, heaven and the heaven of heavens cannot contain You. How much less can this house that I have built?
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet give consideration to the prayer of Your servant and to his supplication, O Lord my God; listen to the cry and to the prayer which Your servant prays before You today,
speaker: Narrator

text: that Your eyes may be upon this house night and day, even toward the place of which You have said, ‘My name shall be there,’ that You may listen to the prayer which Your servant shall make toward this place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Please listen to the supplication of Your servant and of Your people Israel when they pray toward this place. May You hear in heaven, Your dwelling place, and when You hear, forgive.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If any man sins against his neighbor, and an oath be laid upon him to cause him to swear, and the oath comes before Your altar in this house,
speaker: Narrator

text: then may You hear in heaven and act and judge Your servants, condemning the wicked, bringing his way on his own head, and justifying the righteous, giving him according to his righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When Your people Israel are defeated by their enemies, because they have sinned against You, and they turn back to You and call upon Your name and pray and make supplication to You in this house,
speaker: Narrator

text: then may You hear in heaven and forgive the sin of Your people Israel and bring them again to the land which You gave to their fathers.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When heaven is shut up, and there is no rain, because they have sinned against You, if they pray toward this place and call upon Your name and turn from their sin when You afflict them,
speaker: Narrator

text: then may You hear in heaven and forgive the sin of Your servants and Your people Israel, that You may teach them the good way in which they should walk and give rain upon Your land which You have given to Your people as an inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When there is famine in the land, if there is plague, blight, mildew, locust, or grasshopper; if their enemy besieges them in the land of their cities; whatever plague, whatever sickness there is;
speaker: Narrator

text: whatever prayer, whatever supplication is made by anyone, or by all Your people Israel, each knowing the affliction of his own heart, and spreading his hands toward this house;
speaker: Narrator

text: then hear in heaven Your dwelling place, and forgive, and act, and render to everyone according to all his ways, whose hearts You know—for only You know the hearts of the sons of men—
speaker: Narrator

text: so that they may fear You all the days that they live in the land that You gave to our fathers.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Also concerning the foreigner who is not of Your people Israel and comes from a far country for Your name’s sake
speaker: Narrator

text: (for they will hear of Your great name and of Your strong hand and of Your outstretched arm), when he comes and prays toward this house,
speaker: Narrator

text: may You hear in heaven, Your dwelling place, and do all that the foreigner asks of You, so all people of the earth will know Your name, to fear You as Your people Israel do, and that they may know that this house, which I have built, is called by Your name.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If Your people go out to battle against their enemy wherever You send them, and they pray to the Lord toward the city which You have chosen and toward the house that I have built for Your name,
speaker: Narrator

text: then may You hear their prayer and supplication in heaven and maintain their cause.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If they sin against You (for there is no man who does not sin), and You get angry with them and hand them over to the enemy so that they are carried away as captives to the land of the enemy, far or near,
speaker: Narrator

text: yet when they come to their senses while in the land where they were carried captives and repent and make supplication to You, saying, ‘We have sinned and have acted perversely and have committed wickedness,’
speaker: Narrator

text: and so return to You with all their hearts and with all their souls in the land of their enemies, who carried them away as captives, and pray to You toward their land, which You gave to their fathers, the city which You have chosen and the house which I have built for Your name,
speaker: Narrator

text: then may You hear their prayers and supplications in heaven, Your dwelling place, and maintain their cause,
speaker: Narrator

text: and forgive Your people who have sinned against You and all their transgressions which they committed against You and grant them compassion before those who carried them away as captives, so they will have compassion on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For they are Your people and Your inheritance whom You brought forth out of Egypt from the midst of the furnace of iron.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Let Your eyes be open to the supplication of Your servant and to the supplication of Your people Israel, to listen to them regarding all for which they call upon You.
speaker: Narrator

text: For You did call them out from among all the people of the earth to be Your inheritance, as You spoke by the hand of Moses Your servant when You brought our fathers out of Egypt, O Lord God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when Solomon finished praying this prayer and making supplication to the Lord, he arose from before the altar of the Lord, from kneeling on his knees with his hands spread up to heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: He stood up and blessed all the congregation of Israel with a loud voice, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Blessed be the Lord who has given rest to His people Israel according to all that He promised. Not one word of His promises which He gave by the hand of Moses His servant has failed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord our God be with us, as He was with our fathers. Let Him neither leave us nor forsake us,
speaker: Narrator

text: that He may incline our hearts to Him, to walk in all His ways and to keep His commandments, statutes, and judgments, which He commanded our fathers.
speaker: Narrator

text: And let these my words, with which I have made supplication before the Lord, be close to the Lord our God day and night, that He will maintain the cause of His servant and the cause of His people Israel at all times as the situation demands,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that all the people of the earth may know that the Lord is God and that there is none else.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let your hearts, therefore, be perfect with the Lord our God, to walk in His statutes and keep His commandments, as at this day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king and all Israel with him offered sacrifices before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon offered a sacrifice of peace offerings, which he offered to the Lord, twenty-two thousand oxen and a hundred and twenty thousand sheep. So the king and all the children of Israel dedicated the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The same day the king consecrated the middle of the court that was in front of the house of the Lord, for there he offered burnt offerings and meat offerings and the fat of the peace offerings, because the bronze altar that was before the Lord was too little to receive the burnt offerings and meat offerings and the fat of the peace offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time, Solomon held a feast for all Israel, a great congregation, from the entry of Lebo Hamath to the Brook of Egypt, before the Lord our God, seven days and another seven days, a total of fourteen days.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the eighth day he sent the people away, and they blessed the king and went to their tents rejoicing in their hearts for all the goodness that the Lord had done for David His servant and for Israel His people.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Solomon had finished building the house of the Lord and the king’s house and all else he desired,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Lord appeared to Solomon a second time, as He had appeared to him at Gibeon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord said to him,
“I have heard your prayer and supplication, which you made before Me. I have consecrated this house which you built by putting My name there forever. And My eyes and My heart shall be there perpetually.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you will walk before Me, as your father David walked, in integrity of heart and uprightness, so that you are obedient to do all that I have commanded you, and will keep My statutes and My judgments,
speaker: Narrator

text: then I will establish the throne of your kingdom upon Israel forever, just as I promised to your father David, saying, ‘You shall not fail to have a man upon the throne of Israel.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But if you and your sons turn in any way from following Me and do not keep My commandments and My statutes which I have set before you, but go and serve other gods and worship them,
speaker: Narrator

text: then I will cut Israel out of the land which I have given them, and I will cast this house, which I have consecrated for My name, out of My sight, and Israel shall be a proverb and a byword among all people.
speaker: Narrator

text: And everyone who passes by this high house will be astonished and will hiss, and they shall say, ‘Why has the Lord done this to this land, and to this house?’
speaker: Narrator

text: And they will answer, ‘Because they forsook the Lord their God, who brought their fathers out of the land of Egypt, and took hold of other gods and have worshipped and served them. That is why the Lord has brought all this disaster upon them.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: When twenty years had passed since Solomon had built the two houses, the house of the Lord and the king’s house
speaker: Narrator

text: (now Hiram the king of Tyre had furnished Solomon with cedar and fir trees, along with gold, as he had requested), King Solomon gave Hiram twenty cities in the land of Galilee.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hiram came out from Tyre to see the cities Solomon had given him, and he was not pleased with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “What cities are these which you have given me, my brother?” And he called them the land of Kabul to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hiram sent to the king one hundred and twenty talents of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the account of the forced labor which King Solomon conscripted to build the house of the Lord and his own house, Millo, the wall of Jerusalem, Hazor, Megiddo, and Gezer.
speaker: Narrator

text: For Pharaoh, king of Egypt, had gone up against and conquered Gezer and burned it with fire and slain the Canaanites that lived in the city and given it as a present to his daughter, Solomon’s wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon built Gezer and Lower Beth Horon
speaker: Narrator

text: and Baalath and Tadmor in the wilderness, in the land,
speaker: Narrator

text: and all the storage cities that Solomon had, cities for his chariots and cities for his horsemen and all that which Solomon desired to build in Jerusalem and in Lebanon and in all the land of his dominion.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people who were left of the Amorites, Hittites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites, who were not children of Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of those who were left in the land and whom the people of Israel were not able to utterly destroy, were conscripted by Solomon for slave labor to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Solomon did not make any children of Israel into slaves, but instead used them as men of war, as his servants, his leaders, his captains, rulers of his chariots, and his horsemen.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the chief officers over Solomon’s work, five hundred and fifty, who ruled over the people who did the labor.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Pharaoh’s daughter moved out of the City of David to her house which Solomon had built for her, and he then built Millo.
speaker: Narrator

text: Three times a year Solomon offered burnt offerings and peace offerings on the altar that he built to the Lord, and he burned incense on the altar that was before the Lord. So he finished the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Solomon built a fleet of ships in Ezion Geber, which is beside Elath on the shore of the Red Sea in the land of Edom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hiram sent shipmen who had knowledge of the sea to serve alongside Solomon’s men.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went to Ophir and acquired four hundred and twenty talents of gold there and brought it to King Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when the queen of Sheba heard of Solomon’s fame connected to the name of the Lord, she came to test him with hard questions.
speaker: Narrator

text: She came to Jerusalem with a very great retinue, with camels bearing spices, and very much gold, and precious stones; and when she came to Solomon, she told him all that was on her mind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon answered all her questions; there was not anything too difficult for the king which he could not answer.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the queen of Sheba observed Solomon’s wisdom and the house he had built
speaker: Narrator

text: and the meat of his table and the sitting of his servants and the attendance of his ministers and their clothing and his cupbearers and his entryway by which he went up to the house of the Lord, it took her breath away.
speaker: Narrator

text: She said to the king, “What I heard in my own land about your acts and your wisdom was true!
speaker: Narrator

text: I did not believe it until I came and saw it with my own eyes! In fact, I was not even told half. Your wisdom and prosperity are greater than the stories I heard!
speaker: Narrator

text: Happy are your men, and happy are these your servants who stand continually before you and hear your wisdom!
speaker: Narrator

text: Blessed be the Lord your God, who delighted in you and set you on the throne of Israel, because the Lord loved Israel forever; therefore He made you king in order to execute judgment and justice.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She gave the king a hundred and twenty talents of gold and a great amount of spices and precious stones. No one gave as many spices as the queen of Sheba gave to King Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: The ships of Hiram, which brought gold from Ophir, also brought from Ophir a large quantity of almug wood and precious stones.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king made pillars for the house of the Lord out of the almug trees and harps also and psalteries for singers for the king’s house. Never before had such almug wood been brought, nor has any such been seen to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Solomon gave to the queen of Sheba all she desired, no matter what she asked for, in addition to what Solomon gave her from his royal bounty. So she turned and went to her own country, she and her servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the weight of gold that came to Solomon in one year was six hundred and sixty-six talents of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: In addition, he collected from the merchantmen and the traffic of the spice merchants and from all the kings of Arabia and the governors of the country.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Solomon made two hundred large shields of beaten gold made of six hundred shekels of gold each.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made three hundred shields of beaten gold with three pounds of gold in each shield. And the king put them in the House of the Forest of Lebanon.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king also made a great throne of ivory and overlaid it with the best gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: The throne had six steps, and the back of the throne was round, and there were armrests on either side of the seat with two lions standing beside the armrests.
speaker: Narrator

text: Twelve lions stood on the sides of the six steps, and there was no other like it in any kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of King Solomon’s drinking cups were made of gold, and all the cups of the House of the Forest of Lebanon were made of pure gold. None were made of silver, for it was not considered valuable in the days of Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the king had ships at sea at Tarshish with the ships of Hiram. Every three years the ships of Tarshish came bringing gold, silver, ivory, apes, and peacocks.
speaker: Narrator

text: So King Solomon exceeded all the kings of the earth in terms of riches and wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the earth came to Solomon to hear his wisdom, which God had put in his heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone brought an annual tribute in the form of presents, silver and gold cups, garments, armor, spices, horses, and mules.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon gathered together chariots and horsemen. He had one thousand four hundred chariots and twelve thousand horsemen whom he stationed in the cities for chariots and with the king at Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king made silver to be in Jerusalem as plentiful as stones, and he made cedars to be as plentiful as sycamore trees in the valley.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon had horses brought out of Egypt along with linen yarn. The king’s merchants received the linen yarn at a price.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought chariots from Egypt at a price of six hundred shekels of silver and a horse for a hundred and fifty. And he exported them to all the kings of the Hittites and the kings of Aram, by their means.
speaker: Narrator

text: But King Solomon loved many foreign women in addition to the daughter of Pharaoh, women of the Moabites, Ammonites, Edomites, Sidonians, and Hittites,
speaker: Narrator

text: from the nations which the Lord warned the children of Israel about, saying, “You shall not go in to them, nor shall they come in to you, for they will surely turn your heart away toward their gods.” Solomon clung to these in love.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had seven hundred wives who were princesses and three hundred concubines, and his wives turned his heart away.
speaker: Narrator

text: For when Solomon was old, his wives turned his heart away after other gods, and his heart was not perfect with the Lord his God as the heart of David his father had been.
speaker: Narrator

text: For Solomon went after Ashtoreth, the goddess of the Sidonians, and after Molek, the abomination of the Ammonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon did what was evil in the sight of the Lord and did not fully follow the Lord as his father David had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Solomon built a high place for Chemosh, the abomination of Moab, in the hill that is close to Jerusalem, and for Molek, the abomination of the children of Ammon.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did the same for all his foreign wives, who burned incense and sacrificed to their gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord was angry with Solomon because he turned his heart away from the Lord God of Israel, who had appeared to him twice,
speaker: Narrator

text: and had warned him about this, that he should not follow other gods, but he was disobedient to the Lord’s command.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore the Lord said to Solomon, “Since you have done this and have not kept My covenant and statutes, which I commanded you, I will surely take the kingdom from you and give it to your servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will not do this in your lifetime for your father David’s sake, but I will tear it out of the hand of your son.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, I will not take the whole kingdom away, but will preserve one tribe for your son for David My servant’s sake and for the sake of Jerusalem which I chose.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord stirred up an adversary against Solomon, Hadad the Edomite. He was a prince of Edom.
speaker: Narrator

text: For when David was in Edom, and Joab the commander of the army had gone to bury the slain, he had killed every male in Edom
speaker: Narrator

text: (for six months Joab stayed there with his men until he had killed every male in Edom).
speaker: Narrator

text: But Hadad fled to Egypt, he and some Edomites who served his father, Hadad still being a small child.
speaker: Narrator

text: They set out from Midian and went to Paran, and they gathered men from Paran and then arrived in Egypt and presented him before Pharaoh king of Egypt, who gave him a house and provisions and land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh had great affection for Hadad, so much so that he gave him his sister-in-law, the sister of Tahpenes the queen, as a wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tahpenes’ sister gave birth to his son, Genubath, whom Tahpenes weaned in Pharaoh’s house. Genubath lived in Pharaoh’s house among the sons of Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Hadad heard in Egypt that David slept with his fathers and that Joab, the commander of the army, was dead, he said to Pharaoh, “Allow me to depart and go to my own country.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Pharaoh said to him, “But what have you lacked with me that you want to go to your own country?”
And he answered, “Nothing, however let me go anyway.”
speaker: Narrator

text: God stirred up another adversary against him, Rezon the son of Eliada, who fled from his lord Hadadezer, king of Zobah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He gathered a group of men and became leader over a band when David killed the men of Zobah, and they fled to Damascus and lived and reigned there.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was an enemy of Israel all the days of Solomon in addition to the troubles caused by Hadad, and he hated Israel and reigned over Aram.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeroboam the son of Nebat, an Ephraimite of Zeredah, who was Solomon’s servant and whose mother’s name was Zeruah, a widow woman, even he lifted up his hand against the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what led to his rebellion against the king. Solomon built Millo and repaired the wall of the City of David his father.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeroboam was a mighty man of valor, and when Solomon saw that the young man was industrious, he made him ruler over all the labor force of the house of Joseph.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time, when Jeroboam went out of Jerusalem, the prophet Ahijah the Shilonite found him along the way, and he had dressed himself in a new garment, and the two of them were alone in the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahijah took off the new garment that he wore and tore it into twelve pieces,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he said to Jeroboam: Take ten pieces, for thus says the Lord, the God of Israel, “See, I will tear the kingdom out of the hand of Solomon and will give ten tribes to you
speaker: Narrator

text: (but he shall have one tribe for My servant David’s sake and for the sake of Jerusalem, the city which I have chosen out of all the tribes of Israel),
speaker: Narrator

text: because they have forsaken Me and have worshipped Ashtoreth the goddess of the Sidonians, Chemosh the god of the Moabites, and Molek the god of the children of Ammon and have not walked in My ways and have not done that which is right in My eyes, to keep My statutes and judgments, as his father David had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: “However, I will not take the whole kingdom out of his hand, but I will make him prince all the days of his life for David My servant’s sake, whom I chose, because he kept My commandments and My statutes.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I will take the kingdom out of his son’s hand and will give ten tribes to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: To his son will I give one tribe, so that My servant David will always have a light before Me in Jerusalem, the city in which I have chosen to put My name.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will take you, and you shall reign according to all that your soul desires and shall be king over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: It shall be, if you will listen to all that I command you and will walk in My ways and do what is right in My sight to keep My statutes and My commandments, as David My servant did, I will be with you and build you a sure house, as I built for David, and will give Israel to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will thus afflict the seed of David, but not forever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon therefore sought to kill Jeroboam. And Jeroboam arose and fled to Egypt to Shishak, king of Egypt, and he stayed in Egypt until the death of Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the acts of Solomon and all that he did and his wisdom, are they not written in the book of the acts of Solomon?
speaker: Narrator

text: And the time that Solomon reigned in Jerusalem over all Israel was forty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon slept with his fathers and was buried in the City of David his father, and his son Rehoboam reigned after him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Rehoboam went to Shechem, for all Israel had gone to Shechem to make him king.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jeroboam the son of Nebat, who was still in Egypt, heard of it (for he had fled from King Solomon and stayed in Egypt),
speaker: Narrator

text: they called and sent for him. And Jeroboam and all the congregation of Israel came and spoke to Rehoboam, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Your father made our yoke unbearable. Now, therefore, make the grievous service to your father and the heavy yoke he put upon us lighter, and we will serve you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “Depart for three days, and then come back to me.” And the people departed.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Rehoboam consulted with the old men who advised his father Solomon while he was still alive and asked, “How do you advise me to answer the people?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And they spoke to him, saying, “If you will be a servant to this people this day and will serve them and answer them and speak kind words to them, they will be your servants forever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he rejected the advice that the old men gave him and consulted with the young men who grew up with him and who stood before him,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he said to them, “What advice do you give on how we should answer this people, who have spoken to me saying, ‘Make the yoke your father put on us lighter’?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the young men who grew up with him said, “Thus shall you answer this people who said to you, ‘Your father made our yoke heavy, but make it lighter for us’; thus shall you say to them, ‘My little finger will be thicker than my father’s loins!
speaker: Narrator

text: Whereas my father loaded you with a heavy yoke, I will add to your burden. My father chastised you with whips, but I will chastise you with scorpions!’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jeroboam and all the people came to Rehoboam on the third day, just as the king had appointed, saying, “Come to me again the third day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king answered the people roughly and forsook the counsel the old men gave him,
speaker: Narrator

text: and instead spoke to them following the advice of the young men. He said, “My father made your yoke heavy, and I will add to your burden. My father chastised you with whips, but I will chastise you with scorpions.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus the king did not listen to the people, for the cause was from the Lord, that He might fulfill His saying, which the Lord spoke by Ahijah the Shilonite to Jeroboam the son of Nebat.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So when all Israel saw that the king did not listen to them, the people responded to the king, saying,
“What portion do we have in David?
    We also do not have an inheritance in the son of Jesse.
To your tents, O Israel,
    and see to your own house, David!”
So the people of Israel departed to their tents.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the people of Israel living in the cities of Judah were ruled over by Rehoboam.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King Rehoboam sent Adoniram, who was in charge of the forced labor, and all Israel stoned him to death. As a result, King Rehoboam quickly mounted his chariot and fled to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Israel rebelled against the house of David, and it remains so even to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all Israel heard that Jeroboam had returned, they sent and called him before the congregation and made him king over all Israel. Only the tribe of Judah followed the house of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Rehoboam arrived at Jerusalem, he assembled all the house of Judah along with the tribe of Benjamin, a hundred and eighty thousand chosen men who were warriors, to fight against the house of Israel and to bring the kingdom back to Rehoboam the son of Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the word of God came to Shemaiah the man of God, saying:
speaker: Narrator

text: Speak to Rehoboam the son of Solomon, king of Judah, and to all the house of Judah and Benjamin and to the remnant of the people, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Thus says the Lord: You shall not go up, nor fight against your brothers the children of Israel. Every man is to return to his house, for this thing is from Me.” They listened therefore to the word of the Lord and turned to depart, according to the word of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jeroboam built Shechem in Mount Ephraim and lived there and went out from there and built Peniel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeroboam said in his heart, “The kingdom will return to the house of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: If this people go up to do sacrifice in the house of the Lord at Jerusalem, then shall the heart of this people turn again to their lord, even to Rehoboam king of Judah, and they shall kill me and go again to Rehoboam king of Judah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: At that point, the king got some advice and made two golden calves and said to the people, “It is too difficult for you to go up to Jerusalem. Here are your gods, O Israel, which brought you up out of the land of Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He set one in Bethel, and he put the other in Dan.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was a sin, for the people went to worship before the one, even all the way in Dan.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also made houses on high places and appointed priests from among all the people who were not Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeroboam ordained a feast in the eighth month, on the fifteenth day of the month, like the feast in Judah, and he offered sacrifice on the altar. He did this in Bethel, sacrificing to the calves that he had made, and he stationed in Bethel the priests of the high places he had made.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he made offerings on the altar that he had made in Bethel on the fifteenth day of the eighth month, a holiday he imagined in his own heart, and ordained a feast for the children of Israel, and he sacrificed on the altar and burned incense.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man of God came out of Judah to Bethel by the word of the Lord while Jeroboam stood by the altar to burn incense.
speaker: Narrator

text: He cried against the altar by the word of the Lord and said, “O altar, altar, thus says the Lord: ‘A child named Josiah will be born in the house of David, and he will sacrifice upon you the priests of the high places who burn incense on you, and these men’s bones shall be burned upon you.’ ”
speaker: Narrator
