text: He gave a sign the same day, saying, “This is the sign that the Lord has spoken: ‘The altar will be torn apart, and the ashes that are upon it will be poured out.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: When King Jeroboam heard the saying of the man of God who had cried against the altar in Bethel, he reached out his hand from the altar, saying, “Arrest him!” And the hand that he put forth against him dried up so that he could not pull it back in again.
speaker: Narrator

text: The altar also was torn, and the ashes poured out from the altar, just as the man of God had said it would as a sign of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king answered and said to the man of God, “Seek the face of the Lord your God, and pray for me, that my hand will be healed.” And the man of God interceded with the Lord, and the king’s hand was healed and became as it was before.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said to the man of God, “Come home with me and refresh yourself, and I will give you a reward.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The man of God said to the king, “If you were to give me half your house, I would not go with you, nor will I eat bread nor drink water in this place,
speaker: Narrator

text: for so I was commanded by the word of the Lord, saying: You shall eat no bread, nor drink water nor return by the same way that you came.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he went another way and did not return by the same way he came to Bethel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there lived an old prophet in Bethel, and his sons came and told him all that the man of God had done that day in Bethel. They also told their father the words that he had spoken to the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their father said to them, “What way did he go?” For his sons had seen the way the man of God who came from Judah had gone.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to his sons, “Saddle my donkey.” So they saddled the donkey for him, and he rode on it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He went after the man of God and found him sitting under an oak, and he said to him, “Are you the man of God who came from Judah?”
And he said, “I am.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to him, “Come home with me and eat bread.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “I may not return with you or go in with you, nor will I eat bread nor drink water with you in this place,
speaker: Narrator

text: for I was commanded by the word of the Lord: You shall eat no bread and drink no water there nor return by the way you came.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to him, “I am a prophet like you, and an angel spoke to me by the word of the Lord, saying, ‘Bring him back with you into your house so that he may eat bread and drink water.’ ” But he had lied to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he went back with him to his house and ate bread and drank water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then as they sat at the table, the word of the Lord came to the prophet who brought him back,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he cried out to the man of God who came from Judah, saying, “Thus says the Lord: Since you have disobeyed the mouth of the Lord and have not kept the commandment that the Lord your God commanded you,
speaker: Narrator

text: but instead came back and have eaten bread and drunk water in the place of which the Lord told you to eat no bread and drink no water, your carcass will not be buried in the tomb of your fathers!”
speaker: Narrator

text: After he had eaten bread and had drunk, he saddled the donkey for the prophet whom he had brought back.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he was going, a lion met him on the way and killed him, and his body was thrown in the road, and both the donkey and lion stood by it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some men passed by and saw the body thrown in the road with the lion standing by the body, and they came and told the story in the city where the old prophet lived.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the prophet who brought him back from the way heard about it, he said, “It is the man of God who was disobedient to the word of the Lord, and thus the Lord has delivered him to the lion, which has torn and slain him, according to the word of the Lord that He spoke to him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to his sons, “Saddle my donkey,” and they saddled it.
speaker: Narrator

text: He then went and found his body thrown in the road, and the donkey and the lion were still standing by the body. The lion had not eaten the body nor attacked the donkey.
speaker: Narrator

text: The prophet picked up the body of the man of God and laid it on his donkey and brought it back. The old prophet came to the city to mourn and to bury him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He laid his body in his own tomb, and they mourned over him, saying, “Alas, my brother!”
speaker: Narrator

text: And after he had buried him, he said to his sons, “When I am dead, bury me in the grave in which the man of God is buried; lay my bones beside his bones.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the saying that he cried out by the word of the Lord against the altar in Bethel and against all the houses of the high places that are in the cities of Samaria shall surely come to pass.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After this event Jeroboam did not turn from his evil ways, but made priests for the high places again from among all the people. Any who would, he consecrated to be priests of the high places.
speaker: Narrator

text: This matter became sin to the house of Jeroboam, so as to cut it off and to destroy it from the face of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time, Jeroboam’s son Abijah became sick.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeroboam said to his wife, “Please get up and disguise yourself, so that you will not be recognized as the wife of Jeroboam, and go to Shiloh. There you will find Ahijah the prophet, who told me that I would be king over this people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take ten loaves, cakes, and a jar of honey, and go to him. He will tell you what will happen to our child.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jeroboam’s wife did so and arose and went to Shiloh, to the house of Ahijah.
But Ahijah could not see, for in his old age he had gone blind.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Ahijah, “The wife of Jeroboam has come to ask you about her son, for he is sick. You shall say thus and thus to her, for when she comes, she will be disguised as another woman.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And so when Ahijah heard the sound of her feet as she came in the door, he said, “Come in, wife of Jeroboam. Why do you disguise yourself as another? I have been sent to you with bad news.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go tell Jeroboam, ‘Thus says the Lord God of Israel: I raised you up from among the people and made you prince over My people Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: and took the kingdom away from the house of David and gave it you. Yet you have not been as My servant David, who kept My commandments and who followed Me with all his heart to do only that which was right in My eyes,
speaker: Narrator

text: but you have sinned more than all who were before you, for you have gone and made other gods and molded images and provoked Me to anger and have cast Me behind your back.
speaker: Narrator

text: “ ‘Therefore I will bring disaster upon the house of Jeroboam and will cut off from Jeroboam all males, both slave and free in Israel, and will take away the remnant of the house of Jeroboam, as a man takes away refuse until it is all gone.
speaker: Narrator

text: Descendants of Jeroboam who die in the city will be eaten by dogs, and those who die in the field will be eaten by the birds of the air, for the Lord has spoken it.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Arise therefore and go to your own house. When your feet enter the city, the child will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: All Israel will mourn for him and bury him, for he alone from the house of Jeroboam will come to the grave, because in him there is found some good thing toward the Lord God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Moreover the Lord will raise up a king over Israel who will destroy the house of Jeroboam this day and from now on.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord will smite Israel, as a reed is shaken in the water, and He will uproot Israel from this good land, which he gave to their fathers, and will scatter them beyond the river, because they have made their Asherah poles, provoking the Lord to anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: He shall give Israel up because of the sins of Jeroboam who sinned and who led Israel to sin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeroboam’s wife arose and departed and came to Tirzah. As she arrived at the threshold of the door, the child died,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they buried him, and all Israel mourned for him, according to the word of the Lord, which He spoke by the hand of His servant Ahijah the prophet.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the acts of Jeroboam, how he waged war and how he reigned, are written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeroboam reigned twenty-two years, and then he slept with his fathers, and Nadab, his son, reigned in his stead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rehoboam the son of Solomon reigned in Judah. Rehoboam was forty-one years old when he began to reign, and he reigned seventeen years in Jerusalem, the city which the Lord had chosen out of all the tribes of Israel to put His name there. And his mother’s name was Naamah, an Ammonitess.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah did evil in the sight of the Lord, and the people provoked Him to jealousy with the sins they committed, even worse than their fathers had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: For they also built high places and images and Asherah poles on every high hill and under every green tree.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were also male cult prostitutes in the land, and they did according to all the abominations of the nations that the Lord cast out before the children of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fifth year of King Rehoboam, Shishak king of Egypt came up against Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took away all the treasures of the house of the Lord and the treasures of the king’s house, even all the shields of gold which Solomon had made.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Rehoboam replaced them with bronze shields and committed them to the hands of the chief of the guard who guarded the king’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: And whenever the king entered the house of the Lord, the guards carried them and brought them back into the guard chamber.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the acts of Rehoboam and all that he did, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: There was war between Rehoboam and Jeroboam all their days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rehoboam slept with his fathers and was buried with his fathers in the City of David. And his mother’s name was Naamah, an Ammonitess. And Abijah his son reigned in his stead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now in the eighteenth year of King Jeroboam the son of Nebat, Abijah became king over Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He reigned three years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Maakah, the daughter of Abishalom.
speaker: Narrator

text: He walked in all the sins of his father that he had done before him, and his heart was not wholly devoted to the Lord his God as the heart of his father David had been.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, for David’s sake, the Lord his God gave him a lamp in Jerusalem, to set up his son after him and to establish Jerusalem,
speaker: Narrator

text: because David did that which was right in the eyes of the Lord and did not turn aside from anything that He commanded him all the days of his life, except in the matter involving Uriah the Hittite.
speaker: Narrator

text: The war begun between Rehoboam and Jeroboam continued all the days of his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the acts of Abijah and all that he did, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah? And there was war between Abijah and Jeroboam.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abijah slept with his fathers, and they buried him in the City of David, and Asa his son reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the twentieth year of Jeroboam king of Israel, Asa became king over Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He reigned forty-one years in Jerusalem, and his grandmother’s name was Maakah, the daughter of Abishalom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Asa did what was right in the eyes of the Lord, just as his father David had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: He expelled the male cult prostitutes from the land and removed all the idols that his fathers had made.
speaker: Narrator

text: In addition he even deposed his grandmother Maakah as queen, because she had made an idol in a grove. Asa destroyed her idol and burned it by the Kidron brook.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the high places were not all removed, even though Asa’s heart was wholly devoted to the Lord all his days.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought into the house of the Lord the things that both his father and he himself had dedicated, the silver and gold and cups.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was war between Asa and Baasha king of Israel all their days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Baasha king of Israel went up against Judah and fortified Ramah so he could prevent anyone from going out or coming in to Asa king of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Asa took all the silver and the gold that were left in the treasures of the house of the Lord, as well as the treasures of the king’s house, and delivered them into the hand of his servants, and he sent them to Ben-Hadad, the son of Tabrimmon, the son of Hezion, king of Aram, who lived at Damascus, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “There is a treaty between me and you and between my father and your father. I have sent to you a present of silver and gold. Come and break your treaty with Baasha king of Israel, so he will depart from me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Ben-Hadad listened to King Asa and sent the commanders of his armies against the cities of Israel and conquered Ijon, Dan, Abel Beth Maakah, and all Kinnereth, along with all the land of Naphtali.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Baasha heard about it, he halted the fortification of Ramah and moved to Tirzah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King Asa made a proclamation throughout all Judah—none was exempted—and they took away the stones of Ramah and the timber with which Baasha had built, and King Asa used them to build Geba of Benjamin as well as Mizpah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of all the acts of Asa and all his might and all that he did and the cities that he built, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah? When he was old, he got a disease in his feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Asa then slept with his fathers and was buried with them in the city of his father David, and Jehoshaphat his son reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nadab the son of Jeroboam began to reign over Israel in the second year of Asa king of Judah and reigned over Israel two years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the sight of the Lord and walked in the way of his father and in his sin with which he made Israel to sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Baasha the son of Ahijah of the house of Issachar conspired against him, and Baasha killed him at Gibbethon, which belonged to the Philistines, for Nadab and all Israel laid siege to Gibbethon.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was in the third year of Asa king of Judah that Baasha killed him and took his throne.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he became king, Baasha killed all the house of Jeroboam. No one from Jeroboam’s family was left breathing. He completely destroyed them, according to the word of the Lord which He spoke by His servant Ahijah the Shilonite,
speaker: Narrator

text: because of the sins of Jeroboam which he sinned and which he made Israel sin, by his provocation with which he provoked the Lord God of Israel to anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the acts of Nadab and all that he did, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: And there was war between Asa and Baasha king of Israel all their days.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the third year of Asa king of Judah, Baasha the son of Ahijah began to reign over all Israel in Tirzah, and he did so twenty-four years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the sight of the Lord and walked in the way of Jeroboam and in his sin with which he made Israel to sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the word of the Lord came to Jehu the son of Hanani against Baasha, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “I exalted you out of the dust and made you prince over My people Israel, and you have walked in the way of Jeroboam and have made My people Israel to sin, to provoke Me to anger with their sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: See, I will take away the posterity of Baasha and the posterity of his house and will make your house like the house of Jeroboam the son of Nebat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those from the house of Baasha who die in the city will be eaten by dogs, and those who die in the fields will be eaten by the birds of the air.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the acts of Baasha and what he did and his might, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: So Baasha slept with his fathers and was buried in Tirzah, and Elah his son reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: And so it was by the hand of the prophet Jehu the son of Hanani that the word of the Lord came against Baasha and his house, for all the evil that he did in the sight of the Lord in provoking Him to anger with the work of his hands because he acted like the house of Jeroboam and also because he killed it.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the twenty-sixth year of Asa king of Judah, Elah the son of Baasha began to reign over Israel in Tirzah, and he did so two years.
speaker: Narrator

text: His servant Zimri, commander of half his chariots, conspired against him, and when he was in Tirzah, drinking himself drunk in the house of Arza, manager of his house in Tirzah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Zimri went in and smote him and killed him. This took place in the twenty-seventh year of Asa king of Judah, and Zimri reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he began to reign, as soon as he was seated on his throne, he executed all the household of Baasha. He left no males, neither of his relatives nor of his friends.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus Zimri destroyed all the house of Baasha, according to the word of the Lord which He spoke against Baasha by Jehu the prophet,
speaker: Narrator

text: because of all the sins of Baasha and the sins of Elah his son, by which they sinned and by which they made Israel to sin in provoking the Lord God of Israel to anger with their vanities.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the acts of Elah and all that he did, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: In the twenty-seventh year of Asa king of Judah, Zimri reigned seven days in Tirzah. Now the troops were encamped against Gibbethon, which belonged to the Philistines.
speaker: Narrator

text: The troops who were encamped heard how Zimri had conspired and had slain the king. As a result, all Israel made Omri, the commander of the army, king over Israel that day in the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: Omri went up from Gibbethon and all Israel with him, and they besieged Tirzah.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Zimri saw that the city had fallen, he went into the citadel of the king’s house and burned the king’s house over him with fire, and he died,
speaker: Narrator

text: because of his sins which he sinned in doing evil in the sight of the Lord, in walking in the way of Jeroboam and in his sin which he did to make Israel to sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the acts of Zimri and his treason, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the people of Israel were divided into two parts. Half of the people followed Tibni the son of Ginath to make him king, and half followed Omri.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the people who followed Omri defeated the people who followed Tibni, the son of Ginath. So Tibni died, and Omri reigned.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the thirty-first year of Asa king of Judah, Omri began to reign over Israel, and he did so twelve years. He reigned six years in Tirzah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He bought the hill of Samaria from Shemer for two talents of silver. He fortified the hill and named the city he built after the name of Shemer, owner of the hill, calling it “Samaria.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Omri did evil in the eyes of the Lord and did worse than all who preceded him,
speaker: Narrator

text: for he walked in all the ways of Jeroboam the son of Nebat and in his sin with which he made Israel to sin to provoke the Lord God of Israel to anger with their vanities.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the acts Omri performed and his might that he showed, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: So Omri slept with his fathers and was buried in Samaria, and Ahab his son reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the thirty-eighth year of Asa king of Judah, Ahab the son of Omri began to reign over Israel, and Ahab the son of Omri reigned over Israel in Samaria twenty-two years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahab the son of Omri did more evil in the sight of the Lord than all who were before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sins of Jeroboam the son of Nebat were seen as minor for him to walk in, for he took Jezebel the daughter of Ethbaal, king of the Sidonians, as his wife and went and served Baal and worshipped him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He raised an altar for Baal in the house of Baal, which he had built in Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahab made an Asherah and did more to provoke the Lord God of Israel to anger than all the kings of Israel who preceded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: In his days, Hiel the Bethelite built Jericho. He laid the foundation at the expense of his firstborn Abiram and set up the gates at the cost of the life of his youngest son Segub, according to the word of the Lord, which He spoke by Joshua the son of Nun.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Elijah the Tishbite, who was one of the inhabitants of Gilead, said to Ahab, “As the Lord God of Israel lives before whom I stand, there will not be dew or rain these years except by my word.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord came to him, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go from here and turn eastward and hide by the Kerith brook, which is east of the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall drink from the brook, and I have commanded the ravens to feed you there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he went and did according to the word of the Lord, for he went and lived by the Kerith brook, which is east of the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The ravens brought him bread and meat in the morning and bread and meat in the evening, and he drank from the brook.
speaker: Narrator

text: After some time, the brook dried up because there had been no rain in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord came to him, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Arise, go to Zarephath, which belongs to Sidon, and live there. I have commanded a widow there to provide for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he got up and went to Zarephath, and when he came to the gate of the city, a widow was there gathering sticks. He called to her and said, “Please get a small cup of water for me to drink.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As she was going to get it, he called to her and said, “Please bring me a morsel of bread in your hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She said, “As the Lord your God lives, I do not have bread, but only a handful of meal in a barrel and a little oil in a jar. I am gathering two sticks, that I can go in and make it for me and my son, so we may eat it and die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah said to her, “Do not fear; go and do as you have said, but make a little cake for me first, and bring it to me, and afterward, make some for your son and you,
speaker: Narrator

text: for thus says the Lord God of Israel: The barrel of meal will not run out, nor will the jar of oil empty, until the day that the Lord sends rain upon the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She went and did what Elijah told her to do, and she, he, and her household ate many days.
speaker: Narrator

text: The barrel of meal did not run out, nor did the jar of oil empty, according to the word of the Lord, which He spoke by Elijah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later on, the son of the woman, the mistress of the house, became terribly sick, so much so that he had no breath left in him.
speaker: Narrator

text: She said to Elijah, “What do I have to do with you, O you man of God? Have you come to remind me of my sin and to kill my son?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said to her, “Give me your son,” and he took him out of her arms and carried him up to a loft where he slept and laid him on his own bed.
speaker: Narrator

text: He cried to the Lord and said, “O Lord, my God, have You brought tragedy upon the widow with whom I live by killing her son?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he stretched himself upon the child three times and cried to the Lord and said, “O Lord, my God, I pray that You let this child’s soul come into him again.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord heard the voice of Elijah, and the soul of the child came into him again, and he was revived.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah took the child and brought him down out of the chamber into the house and returned him to his mother, and Elijah said, “See, your son lives!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman said to Elijah, “Now, because of this, I know that you are a man of God, and that the word of the Lord in your mouth is truth!”
speaker: Narrator

text: After many days, in the third year, the word of the Lord came to Elijah, saying, “Go and present yourself to Ahab, and I will send rain upon the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Elijah went to show himself to Ahab.
And there was a great famine in Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahab called Obadiah, who was the governor of his house. (Now Obadiah feared the Lord greatly.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jezebel killed the prophets of the Lord, Obadiah took a hundred prophets and hid them in groups of fifty in a cave and fed them with bread and water.)
speaker: Narrator

text: And Ahab said to Obadiah, “Go into the land, to all the springs of water and to all the brooks. Perhaps we will find grass to save the horses and mules, so that we do not lose all the beasts.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they divided the land between them to search throughout it. Ahab went one way by himself, and Obadiah went another way by himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: As Obadiah was going along, he met Elijah, and he recognized him and fell on his face and said, “Is that you, my lord Elijah?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he answered him, “I am. Go, tell your lord, ‘Elijah is here.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “What evil have I done that you would hand your servant into the hand of Ahab to put me to death?
speaker: Narrator

text: As the Lord your God lives, there is no nation or kingdom where my lord has not looked for you, and when they said, ‘He is not here,’ he made the kingdom and nation swear that they could not find you,
speaker: Narrator

text: and now you say, ‘Go, tell your lord, “Elijah is here!” ’
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as I am gone from you, the Spirit of the Lord will carry you to a place I do not know, and so when I come and tell Ahab and he cannot find you, he will execute me. But I, your servant, have feared the Lord since my youth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Were you not told what I did when Jezebel killed the prophets of the Lord, how I hid a hundred men of the Lord’s prophets in groups of fifty in a cave and fed them with bread and water?
speaker: Narrator

text: And now you say, ‘Go, tell your lord, “Elijah is here,” ’ and he will execute me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah said, “As the Lord of Hosts lives, before whom I stand, I will surely show myself to him today.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Obadiah went to meet Ahab and told him. And Ahab went to meet Elijah.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Ahab saw Elijah, Ahab said to him, “Are you he that troubles Israel?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he answered, “I have not troubled Israel, but you and your father’s house, in that you have forsaken the commandments of the Lord and you have followed the Baals.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now send word out and gather for me all Israel on Mount Carmel, along with the four hundred and fifty prophets of Baal and the four hundred prophets of Asherah who eat at Jezebel’s table.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Ahab called out all the children of Israel and gathered the prophets together on Mount Carmel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Elijah came to all the people and said, “How long will you stay between two opinions? If the Lord is God, follow Him, but if Baal, then follow him.”
And the people did not say a word.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elijah said to the people, “I alone remain a prophet of the Lord, but Baal’s prophets number four hundred and fifty men.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, let them give us two bulls, and let them choose one bull for themselves and cut it in pieces and lay it on some wood, but do not light a fire under it, and I will prepare the other bull, lay it on some wood, and not light a fire underneath it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And you call on the name of your gods, and I will call on the name of the Lord, and the God that answers by fire, let Him be God.”
And all the people answered and said, “It is well spoken.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah said to the prophets of Baal, “Choose one bull for yourselves and prepare it first, for there are many of you, and call on the name of your god, but do not light a fire underneath.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They took the bull which was given to them, and they prepared it and called on the name of Baal from morning until noon, saying, “O Baal, hear us.” But there was no voice, and no one answered. And they leaped upon the altar which was made.
speaker: Narrator

text: By noon, Elijah mocked them, saying, “Cry out loud, for he is a god. Either he is talking or is gone away or is on a journey, or perhaps he is asleep and needs to be awakened.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They cried out loud and cut themselves with knives and spears according to their custom until the blood gushed out on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as midday passed, they prophesied until the time of the offering of the evening sacrifice. But there was no voice. No one answered; no one paid attention.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah said to all the people, “Come near to me.” And all the people came near to him. And he repaired the altar of the Lord that was broken down.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah took twelve stones, according to the number of the tribes of the sons of Jacob, to whom the word of the Lord came saying, “Israel shall be your name,”
speaker: Narrator

text: and he built an altar in the name of the Lord with stones, and he made a trench around the altar, so deep that it could contain two seahs of seed.
speaker: Narrator

text: He arranged the wood and cut the bull in pieces and laid him on the wood and said, “Fill four barrels with water, and pour it on the burnt sacrifice and on the wood.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said, “Do it a second time,” and they did it a second time.
And he said, “Do it a third time,” and they did it the third time.
speaker: Narrator

text: The water ran all around the altar and also filled the trench with water.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the time of the offering of the evening sacrifice, Elijah the prophet came near and said, “The Lord, God of Abraham, Isaac, and of Israel, let it be known this day that You are God in Israel and that I am Your servant and that I have done all these things at Your word.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hear me, O Lord, hear me, so that this people may know that You are the Lord God and that You have turned their hearts back again.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the fire of the Lord fell and consumed the burnt sacrifice and the wood and the stones and the dust and licked up the water that was in the trench.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the people saw it, they fell on their faces and said, “The Lord, He is God! The Lord, He is God!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah said to them, “Arrest the prophets of Baal, and do not let one of them escape.” And they arrested them, and Elijah brought them down to the Kishon brook and executed them there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah said to Ahab, “Get up, eat and drink, for there is a sound of a heavy rainfall.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Ahab got up to eat and drink. And Elijah went up to the top of Carmel, and he threw himself down on the ground and put his face between his knees.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And he said to his servant, “Go up now, and look toward the sea.”
And he went up and looked and said, “There is nothing.”
And he said, “Go again,” seven times.
speaker: Narrator

text:
On the seventh time, he said, “A small cloud as small as a man’s hand is rising out of the sea.”
And he said, “Go up and say to Ahab, ‘Mount your chariot and get down, so that the rain does not stop you.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the meantime, the sky turned black with clouds and wind, and there was a great rain. And Ahab rode and went to Jezreel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The hand of the Lord was on Elijah, and he girded up his loins and ran ahead of Ahab to the entrance of Jezreel.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Ahab told Jezebel all that Elijah had done and how he had executed all the prophets with the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jezebel sent a messenger to Elijah, saying, “So let the gods do to me and more also, if I do not make your life as the life of one of them by tomorrow about this time.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he saw that she was serious, he arose and ran for his life to Beersheba, which belongs to Judah, and left his servant there.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he went a day’s journey into the wilderness and came and sat down under a juniper tree and asked that he might die, saying, “It is enough! Now, O Lord, take my life, for I am not better than my fathers.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As he lay and slept under the juniper tree, an angel touched him and said to him, “Arise and eat.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He looked, and there was a cake baked on coals and a jar of water at his head. And he ate and drank and then lay down again.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord came again a second time and touched him and said, “Arise and eat, because the journey is too great for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He arose and ate and drank and went in the strength of that food forty days and forty nights to Horeb, the mountain of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: He came to a cave and camped there, and the word of the Lord came to him, and He said to him, “Why are you here, Elijah?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said, “I have been very zealous for the Lord, Lord of Hosts, for the children of Israel have forsaken Your covenant, thrown down Your altars, and killed Your prophets with the sword, and I alone am left, and they seek to take my life.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said, “Go and stand on the mountain before the Lord.”
And, behold, the Lord passed by, and a great and strong wind split the mountains and broke in pieces the rocks before the Lord, but the Lord was not in the wind. And after the wind, an earthquake came, but the Lord was not in the earthquake.
speaker: Narrator

text: And after the earthquake, a fire came, but the Lord was not in the fire, and after the fire, a still, small voice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When Elijah heard it, he wrapped his face in his cloak and went out and stood in the entrance to the cave.
And a voice came to him and said, “Why are you here, Elijah?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said, “I have been very zealous for the Lord, Lord of Hosts, because the children of Israel have forsaken Your covenant, thrown down Your altars, and killed your prophets with the sword, and I alone am left, and they seek to take my life.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to him, “Go, return on the road through the Wilderness of Damascus, and when you arrive, anoint Hazael to be king over Aram.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you shall anoint Jehu, the son of Nimshi, to be king over Israel, and you shall anoint Elisha, the son of Shaphat of Abel Meholah, to be prophet in your place.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who escapes the sword of Hazael will be killed by Jehu, and he who escapes the sword of Jehu will be killed by Elisha.
speaker: Narrator

text: Still, I have preserved seven thousand men in Israel for Myself, all of whose knees have not bowed to Baal and whose mouths have not kissed him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he departed from there and found Elisha the son of Shaphat, who was plowing with twelve yoke of oxen before him and he with the twelfth, and Elijah passed by him and threw his cloak on him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He left the oxen and ran after Elijah and said, “Please let me kiss my father and mother, and then I will follow you.”
And he said to him, “Go back, for what have I done to you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he returned from following him and took a yoke of oxen and sacrificed them and boiled their flesh with the yokes from the oxen and gave it to the people, and they ate. Then he got up and went after Elijah and ministered to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Ben-Hadad the king of Aram gathered his army together. Thirty-two kings were with him, with horses and chariots, and he went up and besieged Samaria and fought against it.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent messengers into the city to Ahab king of Israel and said to him, “Thus says Ben-Hadad:
speaker: Narrator

text: Your silver and gold is mine, as are your most attractive wives and children.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel answered, “My lord, O king, just as you have said, I and all that I own are yours.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The messengers came again and said, “Thus says Ben-Hadad: Although I have said that you must give me your silver and gold, your wives and your children,
speaker: Narrator

text: instead I will send my servants tomorrow about this time, and they will search your house and the houses of your servants, and whatever is precious to you, they will put it in their hands and take it away.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king of Israel called all the elders of the land and said, “Please notice how this man is looking for trouble, for he has demanded I give him my wives and children and my silver and gold, and I have not denied his request.”
speaker: Narrator

text: All the elders and all the people said to him, “Do not listen to him or consent to his demands.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore he said to the messengers of Ben-Hadad, “Tell my lord the king: I will comply with the first request of your servant, but this thing I will not do.” And the messengers departed and brought him word again.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Ben-Hadad sent messengers to him and said, “The gods do to me and then some if the dust of Samaria shall suffice for handfuls for all the people who follow me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel answered, “Tell him: Let not he who puts on his armor boast himself as he who takes it off.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Ben-Hadad heard this message as he was drinking with the kings in the pavilions, he said to his servants, “Station yourselves!” And they stationed themselves against the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a prophet came to Ahab king of Israel, saying, “Thus says the Lord: Have you seen this great multitude? See, I will deliver it into your hand this day, and you shall know that I am the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ahab asked, “By whom?”
And he said, “Thus says the Lord: By the young leaders of the provinces.”
Then he said, “Who shall order the battle?”
And he answered, “You.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he counted the young leaders of the provinces, and they were two hundred and thirty-two, and after them he counted all the people, all the children of Israel, and had seven thousand.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went out at noon. But Ben-Hadad and the thirty-two kings who helped him were getting drunk in the pavilions.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The young leaders of the provinces went out first.
Ben-Hadad sent out scouts, and they told him, “Men from Samaria have come out.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “If they have come out peacefully, take them alive, and if they have come out for battle, take them alive.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So these young leaders of the provinces came out of the city, followed by the army.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each one killed his man, and the Arameans fled with Israel pursuing them, but Ben-Hadad, the king of Aram, escaped on a horse with the horsemen.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel went out and attacked the horses and chariots and killed a great number of Arameans.
speaker: Narrator

text: The prophet came to the king of Israel and said, “Go, strengthen yourself and prepare, and see what you do, for next year the king of Aram will come up against you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The servants of the king of Aram said to him, “Their gods are gods of the hills. That is why they were stronger than us, but if we fight against them in the plain, we will surely be stronger than they.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do this: Dismiss the kings, each from his position, and put commanders in their places,
speaker: Narrator

text: and assemble an army like the army that you lost, horse for horse and chariot for chariot, and we will fight them in the plain and will surely be stronger than they.” And he listened to their advice and followed it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next year Ben-Hadad assembled the Arameans and went up to Aphek to fight against Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The children of Israel were assembled and were all present, and they went against them, and the children of Israel camped in front of them like two little flocks of kids, while the Arameans filled the country.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man of God came and spoke to the king of Israel and said, “Thus says the Lord: Because the Arameans have said, ‘The Lord is God of the hills, but He is not God of the valleys,’ I will deliver all this great multitude into your hand, and you will know that I am the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They camped opposite each other for seven days, and on the seventh day, the battle was joined. The children of Israel killed a hundred thousand Aramean footmen in one day.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the rest fled into the city of Aphek, where a wall fell on twenty-seven thousand of the men who were left. And Ben-Hadad fled and came into the city into an inner chamber.
speaker: Narrator

text: His servants said to him, “We have heard that the kings of the house of Israel are merciful kings. Please let us put sackcloth on our loins and ropes on our heads and go out to the king of Israel. Perhaps he will spare your life.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So they girded sackcloth on their loins and put ropes on their heads and came to the king of Israel and said, “Your servant Ben-Hadad says, ‘Please let me live.’ ”
And he said, “Is he still alive? He is my brother!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now the men were diligently looking for a positive sign and quickly took hold of it, and they said, “Your brother Ben-Hadad!”
Then he said, “Go. You bring him.” Then Ben-Hadad came to him and got into the chariot.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ben-Hadad said to him, “I will restore the cities which my father took from your father, and you shall make streets for yourself in Damascus, as my father made in Samaria.”
Then Ahab said, “I will send you away with this covenant.” So he made a covenant with him and sent him away.
speaker: Narrator

text: Speaking in the word of the Lord, a certain man of the sons of the prophets said to his neighbor, “Strike me, please.” But the man refused to strike him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to him, “Because you have not obeyed the voice of the Lord, as soon as you leave me, a lion will kill you.” And as soon as he left him, a lion found and killed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he found another man and said, “Strike me, please.” And the man struck him so that he was wounded.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the prophet departed and waited by the road for the king and disguised himself with ashes on his face.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the king passed by, he cried to the king and said, “Your servant went out into the midst of the battle, and a man turned aside and brought a man to me and said, ‘Keep this man, and if by any means he goes missing, then your life shall be given for his life, or else you shall pay a talent of silver.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
As your servant was busy here and there, he disappeared.”
And the king of Israel said to him, “So shall your judgment be; you have decided it yourself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He quickly took the ashes away from his face, and the king of Israel recognized him as one of the prophets.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to him, “Thus says the Lord, ‘Because you have let go out of your hand a man whom I had appointed to utter destruction, you shall pay for his life with your life and his people with your people.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel went to his house in Samaria angry and depressed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Naboth the Jezreelite had a vineyard in Jezreel right by the palace of Ahab king of Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: And after this Ahab spoke to Naboth, saying, “Give me your vineyard, so that I can have it for a garden of herbs, because it is near to my house, and I will give you a better vineyard for it, or if you prefer, I will give you its worth in money.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Naboth said to Ahab, “The Lord forbid that I should give you the inheritance of my fathers.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahab returned home angry and depressed because of the answer Naboth the Jezreelite had given him, for he had said, “I will not give you the inheritance of my fathers.” He lay down on his bed and sulked and would not eat any bread.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jezebel his wife came to him and said, “Why is your spirit so sad that you refuse to eat bread?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said to her, “Because I spoke to Naboth the Jezreelite and said to him, ‘Give me your vineyard for money; or else, if you prefer, I will give you another vineyard for it.’ And he answered, ‘I will not give you my vineyard.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jezebel his wife said to him, “Are you not the governor of the kingdom of Israel? Get up and eat bread, and let your heart be happy, for I will get the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So she wrote letters in Ahab’s name and sealed them with his seal and sent the letters to the elders and to the nobles that were in the city where Naboth lived.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the letters she wrote,
“Proclaim a fast, and set Naboth on high among the people,
speaker: Narrator

text: and set two men, sons of Belial, before him, to bear witness against him, saying, ‘You blasphemed God and the king.’ And then carry him out and stone him, so that he will die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of his city, the elders and the nobles who lived in his city, did as Jezebel had sent word to them, as it was written in the letters that she had sent to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They proclaimed a fast and set Naboth on high among the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two men, children of Belial, came in and sat in front of him, and the men of Belial witnessed against Naboth in the presence of the people, saying, “Naboth blasphemed God and the king.” Then they carried him out of the city and stoned him to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they sent word to Jezebel, saying, “Naboth has been stoned and is dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jezebel heard that Naboth had been stoned and was dead, she said to Ahab, “Arise, take possession of the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite, which he refused to sell to you for money, for Naboth is not alive, but dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Ahab heard that Naboth was dead, he got up to go down to the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite, to take possession of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord came to Elijah the Tishbite, saying:
speaker: Narrator

text: Arise, go down to meet Ahab, king of Israel, who is in Samaria. He is now in the vineyard of Naboth, where he has gone down to possess it.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall speak to him, saying, “Thus says the Lord: Have you killed and also taken possession?” And you shall speak to him, saying, “Thus says the Lord: In the place where dogs licked the blood of Naboth, dogs will lick your own blood!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ahab said to Elijah, “Have you found me, my enemy?”
And he answered, “I have found you, because you have sold yourself to work evil in the sight of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘See, I will bring disaster upon you and will take away your posterity and will cut off all your males, both free and slave, who are left in Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: and will make your house like the house of Jeroboam the son of Nebat and like the house of Baasha the son of Ahijah, for the provocation with which you have provoked Me to anger and made Israel to sin.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord also spoke of Jezebel, saying, ‘The dogs will eat Jezebel by the wall of Jezreel.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Those from Ahab’s family who die in the city will be eaten by dogs, and those who die in the field will be eaten by birds of the air.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But there were none compared to Ahab, who sold himself to evil deeds in the sight of the Lord, which Jezebel his wife stirred up.
speaker: Narrator

text: He performed the most abominable act in following idols like the Amorites, whom the Lord cast out before the children of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Ahab heard those words, he tore his clothes and put on sackcloth on his flesh and fasted and lay in sackcloth and walked meekly.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord came to Elijah the Tishbite, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “See how Ahab humbles himself before Me? Because he humbles himself before Me, I will not bring the disaster during his lifetime, but during his son’s lifetime I will bring the disaster on his household.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And there were three years without war between Aram and Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the third year, Jehoshaphat king of Judah went to visit the king of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel said to his servants, “You know that Ramoth in Gilead is ours, but we have done nothing to take it out of the hand of the king of Aram!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
And he said to Jehoshaphat, “Will you go with me to battle Ramoth Gilead?”
And Jehoshaphat said to the king of Israel, “I am as you are, my people as your people, my horses as your horses.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat said to the king of Israel, “Please ask for a word from the Lord today.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the king of Israel gathered the prophets together, approximately four hundred men, and said to them, “Shall I go against Ramoth Gilead to battle, or shall I wait?”
And they said, “Go up, for the Lord shall deliver it into the hand of the king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat said, “Is there not a prophet of the Lord here whom we can ask?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
And the king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, “There is still one man, Micaiah the son of Imlah, by whom we can inquire of the Lord. But I hate him because he never prophesies good for me, but always evil.”
And Jehoshaphat said, “Let not the king say so.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king of Israel called an officer and said, “Quickly, bring Micaiah the son of Imlah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel and Jehoshaphat the king of Judah each put on his robes and sat on his throne at the entrance of the gate of Samaria, and all the prophets prophesied before them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zedekiah the son of Kenaanah made horns of iron and said, “Thus says the Lord: With these you shall push the Arameans until you have consumed them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: All the prophets prophesied similarly, saying, “Go up to Ramoth Gilead and prosper, for the Lord will deliver it into the king’s hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The servant who had gone to get Micaiah spoke to him, saying, “See here, the words of the prophets unanimously declare success for the king. Please let your word be like the word of one of them, and speak that which is good.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Micaiah said, “As the Lord lives, I will speak whatever the Lord says to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So he came to the king. And the king said to him, “Micaiah, shall we go against Ramoth Gilead to battle, or shall we wait?”
And he answered him, “Go and prosper, for the Lord will deliver it into the hand of the king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said to him, “How many times must I admonish you to tell me only the truth in the name of the Lord?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said, “I saw all Israel scattered upon the hills, as sheep without a shepherd, and the Lord said, ‘These have no master. Let every man return to his own house in peace.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, “Did I not tell you that he would not prophesy good concerning me, but evil?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said, “Hear, therefore, the word of the Lord: I saw the Lord sitting on His throne, and all the host of heaven standing beside Him on His right hand and on His left.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord said, ‘Who will persuade Ahab so that he will go up and die at Ramoth Gilead?’
“And one said this, and another said that.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a spirit came forth and stood before the Lord and said, ‘I will persuade him.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The Lord said to him, ‘How?’
“And he said, ‘I will go and be a lying spirit in the mouth of all his prophets.’
“And He said, ‘You will be successful and persuade him. Go forth, and do so.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now therefore, the Lord has put a lying spirit in the mouths of all your prophets here, and He has spoken evil concerning you!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Zedekiah the son of Kenaanah walked up and struck Micaiah on the cheek and said, “Which way did the spirit of the Lord go from me in order to speak to you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Micaiah said, “You will see in that day, when you go into an inner chamber to hide.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel said, “Take Micaiah back to Amon the governor of the city and to Joash the king’s son,
speaker: Narrator

text: and say, ‘Thus says the king: Put this man in the prison, and feed him with reduced rations of bread and water until I return safely.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Micaiah said, “If you return safely, the Lord has not spoken through me.” And he said, “Listen, all you people!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat the king of Judah went up to Ramoth Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, “I will disguise myself and enter into the battle, but you wear your robes.” And the king of Israel disguised himself and went into the battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the king of Aram ordered his thirty-two commanders who had control over his chariots, saying, “Fight neither against small nor great, but only against the king of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So when the commanders of the chariots saw Jehoshaphat, they said, “Surely it is the king of Israel.” And they turned aside to fight against him, and Jehoshaphat cried out.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the commanders of the chariots realized that it was not the king of Israel, they turned away from pursuing him.
speaker: Narrator

text: A certain man drew a bow at random and struck the king of Israel between the joints of the armor, and because of this, he said to the driver of his chariot, “Turn around and carry me out of the battle, for I am wounded.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The battle intensified that day, and the king was propped up in his chariot against the Arameans and died that evening, and the blood ran out of the wound into the floor of the chariot.
speaker: Narrator

text: A proclamation went throughout the army as the sun was setting, saying, “Every man is to return to his city, and every man is to return to his own country.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king died and was brought to Samaria, and they buried him there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The chariot was washed in the pool of Samaria, and the dogs licked up the king’s blood, and they washed his armor according to the word which the Lord spoke.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the acts of Ahab and all that he did and the ivory house that he built and all the cities that he built, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: So Ahab slept with his fathers. And Ahaziah his son reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat the son of Asa began to reign over Judah in the fourth year of Ahab king of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat was thirty-five years old when he began to reign, and he reigned twenty-five years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Azubah, the daughter of Shilhi.
speaker: Narrator

text: He walked in all the ways of Asa his father. He did not turn aside, doing that which was right in the eyes of the Lord. Nevertheless, the high places were not taken down, and the people continued to offer sacrifices and burn incense there.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jehoshaphat made peace with the king of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the acts of Jehoshaphat and the strength he showed and how he warred, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: And he exterminated from the land the remnant of the male cult prostitutes who remained in the days of his father Asa.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time there was no king in Edom, and a regent sat in the king’s place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat made ships of Tarshish to go to Ophir for gold, but they never made it there, for the ships were broken at Ezion Geber.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Ahaziah the son of Ahab said to Jehoshaphat, “Let my servants go with your servants in the ships.” But Jehoshaphat did not agree.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat slept with his fathers and was buried with his fathers in the City of David his father, and Jehoram his son reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahaziah the son of Ahab began to reign over Israel in Samaria the seventeenth year of Jehoshaphat king of Judah, and he reigned two years over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did evil in the sight of the Lord and walked in the way of his father and in the way of his mother and in the way of Jeroboam the son of Nebat who made Israel sin,
speaker: Narrator

text: for he served Baal and worshipped him and provoked the Lord God of Israel to anger, according to all that his father had done.
speaker: Narrator
